gold_sents: In 2015, indigent former criminal defendants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants had a practice of imprisoning individuals who had failed to pay court debts without meaningfully determining whether the individuals had the ability to pay the debt.[SENTMARKER]In August 2018, granted plaintiffs’ motion for class certification, and held that the Judges’ policy/practice of not inquiring into the ability of the persons falling within the certified class to pay before they are imprisoned for non-payment of court debts was unconstitutional, and that the Judges’ failure to provide a neutral forum for determination of such persons’ ability to pay was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the lower court on August 23, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants petitioned the Fifth Circuit to rehear the case en banc on September 6, 2019, but the court denied to rehear on September 30.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a petition for writ of certiorari in the U.S. Supreme Court on December 20, 2019.[SENTMARKER]Cert was denied on March 3, 2020.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In January 2017, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, alleging that the city's debt collection policies and practices violated the Due Process and Equal Protection rights of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Civil Rights Act of 1871, as well as the Texas and Texas Constitutions.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to stop enforcing these unconstitutional policies, practices, and procedures against the same class of indigent Municipal Debtors, and in the same manner, as Defendant did against Plaintiffs.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On October 3, 2010, the Louisiana Department of Education filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state was violating the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to provide appropriate education placements, services, and accommodations to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a consent judgment in the state's favor in October 2010.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the state to implement a number of reforms, including providing free appropriate public education to all students, implement appropriate placement and services, provide appropriate accommodations, and provide services and accommodations on the students' behalf.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved a statewide ballot initiative that amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]The Colorado Supreme Court found the amendment unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit held that the amendment violated the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that there was no authority in the Federal Constitution to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.

gold_sents: Current and former Black FDNY employees sued the City of New York alleging racial discrimination in their hiring, promotion, and compensation practices.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought to represent a class of individuals similarly situated who suffered from FDNY's policies that afforded too much discretion to higher-level individuals and fostered a culture of favoritism that harmed Black candidates for hiring and advancement.[SENTMARKER]The City filed a motion to dismiss and the Court partially granted the motion, but sustained the plaintiffs' claims related to the hiring and promotion practices with the FDNY.[SENTMARKER]The City moved for partial summary judgment in May 2020, arguing that the retired class representatives could not seek relief.[SENTMARKER]At the same time, the plaintiffs moved to certify the class.[SENTMARKER]Both motions were pending as of February 11, 2021.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.

gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.

gold_sents: In 2013, a group of religious-based universities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Western District of Oklahoma under the First Amendment, Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Affordable Care Act's requirement that employee and student health plans provide coverage of contraception violated their religious foundings.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate as applied to religious nonprofits violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a per curiam order remanding all seven cases to their respective courts of appeals, and ordered that the parties be given time to come to agreement on ensuring contraceptive access without burdening religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]Following revised HHS policies, the District Court permanently enjoined the defendants from forcing religious organizations to provide contraceptive care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2013, a group of Oklahoma colleges and universities filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma challenging the Affordable Care Act's contraception mandate.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the mandate violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), the Free Exercise, Establishment and Free Speech Clauses of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the Departments can require non-objecting employers to provide contraceptive coverage under their group health plans, but the court was not confronted with the question of whether those beliefs were substantially burdened.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2015, the plaintiffs filed petitions for certiorari to the Supreme Court and did not petition for rehearing to this court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.

gold_sents: On October 21, 2014, the American Immigration Council, National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild and American Civil Liberties Union filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants failed to disclose documents regarding information and practices concerning the expedited removal of families from an Artesia, New Mexico immigration detention center.[SENTMARKER]The production of the requested documents was ordered.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on June 6, 2017.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2014, the ACLU, American Immigration Council, and National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security issued expedited removal orders (I-860) to individuals apprehended and/or detained in Artesia, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 31, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an administrative appeal on August 21, 2015, and the case was settled on October 13, 2015.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2012, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) created the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]In 2017, the Department's acting secretary rescinded the program.[SENTMARKER]The district courts granted a preliminary nationwide injunction, while the third vacated the rescission.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that the acting secretary's decision to rescind DACA was arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Fifth Circuit agreed.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 12, 2019, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a motion for partial summary judgment in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York (Edgardo Ramos) challenging the constitutionality of a number of immigration-related conditions imposed by the Attorney General of the United States (AG).[SENTMARKER]The AG was not statutorily authorized to impose the conditions and, therefore, enjoined their application.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2020, a three-judge panel of the District Court for the District of Columbia held that the exclusion of undocumented immigrants from the tabulation of the total population of the states in the U.S. Census was not ambiguous under the Constitution's language.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the State of New York, the New York Immigrant Law Center, and Common Cause v. Trump, 20-CV-2023 (D.D.C.).[SENTMARKER]The case is not binding on this court.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2012, the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2002 was challenged in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oklahoma by various national, state, and local chambers of commerce and trade associations that represent businesses in Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged associational standing to raise claims of their members.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the District Court entered a preliminary injunction enjoining the Defendants from enforcing the challenged laws.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2011, the Supreme Court issued a ruling in Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting, holding that an Arizona law requiring employers to use the employment authorization system known as E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.

gold_sents: In 2008, two detainees filed a habeas petition and class action suit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Warden of Allegheny County Jail challenging their continued detention pursuant to immigration detainers and alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas relief and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the district court (Judge David S. oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2008, Wilmer Urbina, Omar Romero-Villegas, and others brought this action in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Allegheny County Sheriff's Office and the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to comply with the due process requirements of the Pennsylvania Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 3, 2008 and the plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification on June 11, 2008.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2008, the court denied the motion for discovery.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the parties filed a petition for writ of Habeas Corpus, which was denied on July 23, 2008.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2012, ICE Agents and the State of Mississippi filed claims alleging that deferred action Directive commands ICE officers to violate federal law, compels them to violate their oaths of office, violates the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"), unconstitutionally usurps and encroaches upon the legislative powers of Congress, as defined in Article I of the United States Constitution, and violates the obligation of the executive branch to faithfully execute the law, as required by Article II, Section 3, of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2013, the Court found that ICE Agent Plaintiffs had standing to proceed, but the State of Mississippi did not.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2013, the Court dismissed Plaintiff's claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, finding that the dispute must be governed by the Civil Service Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the judgment of the District Court.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2013, a group of ICE agents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Secretary of the DHS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS had violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the United States Constitution, and the Constitution's Article II, Section 3 of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]7, 2013, 16 Indian guestworkers filed a lawsuit in E.D.Tx.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme by Defendant Signal International.[SENTMARKER]As of July 5, 2018, 20 of the 21 plaintiffs had reached a settlement with the Burnett defendants; the remaining plaintiff's claim was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as to the Signal defendants and Dewan defendants.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2013, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against Signal International, Inc., Global Resources, Inc, Sachin Dewan, Dewan Consultants, and the Burnett Defendants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work as part of a forced labor scheme.[SENTMARKER]The question in the case was whether the defendants’ coercive conduct was such that it could overcome the will of the victim so as to make him render his labor involuntary.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on July 20, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs over $100,000 in damages.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In December 2015, a group of Dallas County residents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Dallas County and Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Dallas County had violated the due process component of the Fifth Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment by detaining plaintiffs solely based on immigration hold, Immigration Detainer, or a request from ICE.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted qualified immunity to Dallas County on the basis of the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In December 2016, the plaintiffs amended the complaint to add the Due Process claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

Garcia; please refer to El Cenizo v. Texas for further information and updates.[SENTMARKER]This case was administratively closed on Oct. 24, 2017 in light of the consolidation.

gold_sents: An individual unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act for damages.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in November 2019.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Plaintiff was unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center (BCADC) from March 24, 2016 until June 8, 2016 without notice of any charges, without a warrant, a notice to appear, or an order of removal in violation of law.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant is therefore liable for damages caused to the Plaintiff pursuant to the Federal Tort Claims Act. See 28 U.S.C.  1346(b)(1); 2674; 2680(h)

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 18, 2014, the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Utah entered final judgment in a lawsuit brought by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (La Raza) and the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) challenging Utah's immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the same court as the Supreme Court's decision in Arizona v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled that the federal government could not preempt state immigration laws that conflict with federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for preliminary injunction, which the Court granted on June 18, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Migrant Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont against the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) and the Secretary of the United States Department of Homeland Security (OHS).[SENTMARKER]Migrant Justice fights for the rights of the approximately 1,500 migrant farm workers in Vermont.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DMV's actions violated their First Amendment rights by sharing information with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in a manner that was motivated by animus against Latinos and other nonwhite individuals.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief, finding that the defendants' actions violated Plaintiffs' Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On July 31, 2018, two non-profit organizations and fifteen individuals filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Trump Administration's implementation of the waiver provision of the Travel Ban (Presidential Proclamation No. 9645), alleging that it violates the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]After the Trump Administration concluded, President Biden revoked the Travel Ban and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the waiver provision of the Administrative Procedure Act violated the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was reassigned to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]On March 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a putative class action in that district.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case on April 10, 2019.

gold_sents: In March 2020, during the outbreak of COVID-19 in the Seattle area, persons critically vulnerable to the disease and held in an immigration detention facility near Seattle filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued ICE and its directors for violation of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that continued detention in the face of a potential outbreak in the detention facility would expose the plaintiffs to substantial harm and amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order seeking immediate release.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the plaintiffs' second motion for a temporary restraining order on April 8.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on April 30, which the court has not yet resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 10, 2005, a woman was taken to the Humboldt County Jail in Eureka, California, where she was forced to disrobe so that she was naked from the waist up in the presence of persons who were not participating in the search and who were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]The woman filed a class action suit against the Sheriff's Office and various unnamed Sheriff Deputy defendants in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case, finding that the defendant's strip search policies, practices, and customs violate the plaintiff's constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also sought to amend her class action complaint to include the deputy who performed the strip search in January 2006.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the deputy's actions violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and that the plaintiff was informed of his identity.

gold_sents: On April 16, 2007, Plaintiff, represented by private attorney Mark E. gold_sents: The Attorney General filed suit against the state of Ohio, its governor, the director of youth services, and the superintendents of its juvenile correctional facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 for an alleged pattern or practice of violating the rights of juvenile detainees under the 14th Amendment, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Ohio failed to protect the youth at its facilities from harm and undue risk of harm, failed to meet their medical and mental health needs, and failed to provide adequate special education services.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed as a result of Department of Justice (DOJ) investigations into the conditions of confinement at the Scioto and Marion centers that began in 2005.[SENTMARKER]The Marion facility closed soon after the first injunction in this case.[SENTMARKER]Ohio achieved substantial compliance in 2015, and the consent decree was terminated on December 3, 2015.

gold_sents: The juvenile plaintiff brought suit against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center, challenging the center's policy of strip-searching all juveniles admitted to the Detention Center, without any reasonable suspicion that the juveniles were concealing weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit overturned the District Court's ruling, holding that the search of the named plaintiff did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the parties reached a monetary settlement before having to relitigate the case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Eighth Circuit held that the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center's blanket policy of strip searching minors arrested for minor or nonfelony offenses, without any individualized determination of reasonable suspicion that the individual was or was likely to be carrying or concealing weapons, drugs or other contraband, violated the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit disagreed, but held that two of the strip searches involved in that case did not violate Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded, concluding that the JDC's security could not justify the blanket deprivation of constitutional rights.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.

gold_sents: In 2010, the U.S. Congress passed the Affordable Care Act (ACA) (“Obamacare”) that expanded Medicare coverage to include additional groups of beneficiaries.[SENTMARKER]Arkansas approved a work requirement in Medicaid as a requirement for health coverage in its amendments on March 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On August 14, 2018, three individuals filed a suit against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), as well as administrators involved in implementing the Arkansas Works Amendments (AMA) in the US District Court for the who lost or risked losing medical coverage due to changes in the AWA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief against the AWA and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 27, 2019, the court held that the AWA work requirement does not advance the purpose of the SSA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment and vacated the approval for Arkansas’s program.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2019, the defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On February 14, 2020, the Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's judgment vacating the Secretary's approval of the Arkansas Works Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court emphasized that providing healthcare coverage is the primary purpose of Medicaid.[SENTMARKER]The court found the Secretary's approval of the Arkansas program to be arbitrary and capricious due to the failure to consider whether the program would result in loss of gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. gold_sents: On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court.[SENTMARKER]The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland.[SENTMARKER]The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes.[SENTMARKER]Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge.[SENTMARKER]One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. consolidated for pretrial proceedings with a separate case filed by the National Family Planning & Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA; a national membership organization of Title X providers that operate or administer more than 3,500 health centers providing family planning services to more than 3.7 million patients each year), a Washington-based NFPRHA member organization, and two health care professionals, challenging the same HHS Rule on behalf of themselves and their patients.[SENTMARKER]Washington and the NFPRHA parties filed preliminary injunctions on March 22, 2019, seeking to prohibit HHS from implementing the Final Rule.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bastian granted plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the Final Rule nationwide until further order of the court.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2019, defendants filed a notice of appeal and motion to stay the preliminary injunction, as well as a notice of interlocutory and preliminary injunction appeal regarding plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2019, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a three-judge panel per curiam decision granting defendant’s motion to stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit noted that the Final Rule was challenged in federal court in California, Oregon, and Washington (this case), and district courts in each case granted plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions on nearly identical grounds.[SENTMARKER]HHS appealed in each case and sought to stay the injunctions pending a decision of the merits of its appeals.[SENTMARKER]The panel found that HHS was likely to prevail on the merits of the case, and that the remaining factors also favored a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]On June 25, 2019, plaintiffs in the Oregon and Washington cases filed an emergency motion for reconsideration en banc regarding the stay.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2019, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ordered that the three cases (California, Oregon, and Washington) be reheard en banc, and that the motions for stay pending appeal granted by the Ninth Circuit panel would not be cited as precedent by or to any court of the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2019, the Ninth Circuit en banc court denied the motions for administrative stay of the three-judge panel’s order granting defendant’s motion to stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The en banc court stated they would proceed expeditiously to rehear and reconsider the merits of Defendant-Appellants’ motions for stay of the district courts’ preliminary injunction orders pending consideration of the appeals on the merits.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 22, 2019, the National Family Planning Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington (Yakima) against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the State of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The NFPRHA challenged the HHS's new regulations to Title X of the Public Health Service Act, pertaining to pre-pregnancy family planning services, in federal court in three states (California, Washington and Oregon) and sought preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The district courts in all three states granted plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions on nearly identical grounds.[SENTMARKER]The court granted HHS' motion for a stay pending appeal of the district court's preliminary injunctions, and the parties filed an emergency motion to rehear and reconsider the merits of the appeals on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The en banc court held that the Final Rule was consistent with  1554 of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), and that plaintiffs were not entitled to the extraordinary remedy of a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for rehearing and reconsideration of the case in the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Court denied the motion for stay of the injunctions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac and the local firefighters' union.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the collective bargaining agreements entered by the Pontiac Fire Department and the local firefighters' union discriminated on the basis of sex and race by explicitly creating and maintaining a dual system for hire and promotion requiring that one out of every thee hires or promotions be given to a minority.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the DOJ and the City of Pontiac reached a settlement that required the City of Pontiac to not engage in any act or practice that discriminated on the basis of race or sex in violation of Title VII in relation to hiring or promotion in the Pontiac Fire Department and to provide remedial relief to those employees and applicants denied hire or promotion as a result of the dual system for hire and promotion.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in October 2008.

gold_sents: This is a case about President Trump's executive order that prohibits racial sensitivity training in federal agencies, contractors, and grant recipients.[SENTMARKER]On October 29, 2020, the National Urban League and National Fair Housing Alliance filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the President, the Secretary of Labor, and the Department of Labor, seeking an injunction, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the executive order violated freedom of speech under the First Amendment by denying benefits to private entities that express ideas the Trump Administration doesn't like.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also argued that the executive order violated the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause because the order was too vague and created with an intent to discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, sex, and/or gender.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, a lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Attorney General, and the Acting Secretary of DHS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS issued a new rule in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and the Refugee Act of 1980 (Refugee Act).[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction and ordered the government to restore the nationwide scope of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed that order to the Ninth Circuit and moved for a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States stayed the district court's July 24, 2019 and September 9, 2019 orders pending disposition of the appeal.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2019, the counties of San Francisco, Santa Clara County, the States of California, Oregon, or Maine, and the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS's final rule entitled 22 "Inadmissibility on Public Charge Grounds" was arbitrary and capricious and violated the Equal Protection guarantees of the Fifth Amendment and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction enjoining the DHS from implementing the rule.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on October 11, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On December 5, 2019, the district court stayed the preliminary injunction, but 6 of the district courts also issued preliminary injunctions prohibiting enforcement of the rule, which were ultimately stayed by the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2018 two US Airmen under pseudonym and OutServe-SLDN, a network of LGBTQ military service-people, filed suit against the U.S. Department of Defense, James Mattis, and Heather Wilson in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that the U.S had violated equal protection under the fifth amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented by Winston and Strawn LLP, LAMBDA Legal Defense and Education Fund, and Outserve-SLDN (now known as the Modern Military Association of America) sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing HIV positive service members to continue to serve and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that they were discharged from their duties in the Air Force due to their HIV status.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Leonie M. Brinkema.[SENTMARKER]On January 11, 2019, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to  prevent the defendants from restricting Roe and Voe and others similarly situated from being promoted, changing duty station, or re-training on the same terms as other service members living with HIV who are not being separated.[SENTMARKER]A hearing was held before Judge Brinkema on February 15, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The same day, Judge Brinkema issued an opinion granting in part and denying in part the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendants from separating or dicharging from military service Richard Roe, Victor Voe, and any other similarly situated active-duty member of the Air Force because they are classified as ineligible for worldwide deployment or deployment to the United States Central Command area due to their HIV-positive status.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the decision on the preliminary injunction to the Fourth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]Oral argument was held on September 18, 2019 before a panel of Fourth Circuit Judges comprised of Judges James A. Wynn Jr, Albert Diaz, and Henry F. gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
